item.title: Opinion: Susan Stamberg, trailblazer and NPR Founding Mother, retires
item.description: NPR Founding Mother Susan Stamberg is retiring. She became the first woman to anchor a nightly national news program in 1972, and helped loosen up the serious, stodgy sound of radio hosts.
item.content:encoded: NPR Founding Mother Susan Stamberg is retiring. She became the first woman to anchor a nightly national news program in 1972, and helped loosen up the serious, stodgy sound of radio hosts.

item.title: In April NPR profiled people who couldn't get their HIV drugs. How are they faring now?
item.description: In Zambia, we met people who are HIV positive, couldn't get drugs to suppress the virus after U.S. aid cuts and were seeing symptoms. We checked in on them — and the man who's been their champion.

item.title: HHS responds to report about autism and acetaminophen
item.description: A report that health secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. has promised will come out this month will look at the causes of autism. Many worry it will have claims unsupported by science.

item.title: The U.S. government is taking a stake in Intel. It's rare — and it has some risks
item.description: In the past, the federal government has taken stakes in American companies during wars or economic crises. But now the government's motivation has more to do with the race for AI chips and technology.

item.title: India's honk-happy drivers are switching to even louder horns
item.description: In India's bustling megacities, honking is a common form of communication among drivers. But in this case, one person's language is another person's noise pollution.

item.title: Judge blocks Trump administration's ending of protections for Venezuelans and Haitians
item.description: A federal judge on Friday blocked the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections for more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela who live in the United States.

item.title: Alcaraz beats Djokovic at the U.S. Open and will meet Sinner for Grand Slam final
item.description: Sinner is trying to become the first repeat men's champion in New York since Roger Federer won the tournament five years in a row. Alcaraz hasn't dropped a set as he pursues his second U.S. Open title.
